Generation I.Red: Known to shoot down flying bugs with precision blasts of ink from the surface of the water.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Known to shoot down flying bugs with precision blasts of ink from the surface of the water.
Generation I.Yellow: If it senses any danger, it will vigorously spray water or a special type of ink from its mouth.
Generation I.Stadium: Uses its tail to keep its balance while spraying ink from its mouth. The ink appears to be for shooting down bugs.

Generation II.Gold: If attacked by a larger enemy, it quickly swims to safety by adeptly controlling its dorsal fin.
Generation II.Silver: Its big, developed fins move rapidly, allowing it to swim backward while still facing forward.
Generation II.Crystal: When they're in a safe location, they can be seen playfully tangling their tails together.
Generation II.Stadium 2: If attacked by a larger enemy, it quickly swims to safety by adeptly controlling its dorsal fin. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) Its big, developed fins move rapidly, allowing it to swim backward while still facing forward. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Horsea eats small insects and moss off of rocks. If the ocean current turns fast, this Pok é mon anchors itself by wrapping its tail around rocks or coral to prevent being washed away.
Generation III.Sapphire: If Horsea senses danger, it will reflexively spray a dense black ink from its mouth and try to escape. This Pok é mon swims by cleverly flapping the fins on its back.
Generation III.Emerald: By cleverly flicking the fins on its back side to side, it moves in any direction while facing forward. It spits ink to escape if it senses danger.
Generation III.FireRed: It maintains balance using its tail, which is wound up like a coil. It may spray ink from its mouth.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Known to shoot down flying bugs with precision blasts of ink from the surface of the water.

Generation IV.Diamond: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits murky ink and flees.
Generation IV.Pearl: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits murky ink and flees.
Generation IV.Platinum: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits murky ink and flees.
Generation IV.HeartGold: If attacked by a larger enemy, it quickly swims to safety by adeptly controlling its well-developed dorsal fin.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Its big, developed fins move rapidly, allowing it to swim backward while still facing forward.

Generation V.Black: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits murky ink and flees.
Generation V.White: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits murky ink and flees.
Generation V.Black 2: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits murky ink and flees.
Generation V.White 2: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits murky ink and flees.

Generation VI.X: Known to shoot down flying bugs with precision blasts of ink from the surface of the water.
Generation VI.Y: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits murky ink and flees.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Horsea eats small insects and moss off of rocks. If the ocean current turns fast, this Pokémon anchors itself by wrapping its tail around rocks or coral to prevent being washed away.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: If Horsea senses danger, it will reflexively spray a dense black ink from its mouth and try to escape. This Pokémon swims by cleverly flapping the fin on its back.

Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: If it senses any danger, it will vigorously spray water or a special type of ink from its mouth.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: If it senses any danger, it will vigorously spray water or a special type of ink from its mouth.

Generation VIII.Sword: Horsea makes its home in oceans with gentle currents. If this Pokémon is under attack, it spits out pitch-black ink and escapes.
Generation VIII.Shield: They swim with dance-like motions and cause whirlpools to form. Horsea compete to see which of them can generate the biggest whirlpool.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits black ink and flees.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It makes its nest in the shade of corals. If it senses danger, it spits black ink and flees.

Generation IX.Scarlet: If attacked—even by a large enemy—Horsea effortlessly swims to safety by utilizing its well-developed dorsal fin.
Generation IX.Violet: It maintains balance using its tail, which is wound up like a coil. It may spray ink from its mouth.
